instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 light liquid damage, concentrated on <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

Reflowed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
Reballed <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>,  <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>.
Verified 20V on all 4 USB-C ports.

Current steadily climbs until peaking at 0.31A 20V before suddenly dropping off to 0.01-0.03A 20V, and remains steady there perpetually.
Trackpad clicks when connected, keyboard is screwed up so not testing with that, otherwise no other signs of life.

Worked through the power on sequence at:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oBr-qxYVfghYimgX6pwkNbwSjpQfYbKq/view[/URL]

Everything is fine until <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> never comes online. The PMIC does not appear to have been hit, so I'm guessing this is a logical issue elsewhere? I skipped testing <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> because that's going to be a PITA with my equipment, but can do so if it's particularly relevant.

Liquid damage was quite light, tested all affected caps, no shorts, and no passives were even damaged severely enough to need replacement.

What should I do from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Did you try DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
No, this is a data critical job and I’m concerned that dfu could negatively impact the data, or complicate the repair by necessitating another dfu revive after everything I try.

What’re your thoughts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Only DFU restore will erase SSD.
Try revive option.
Check at leats if machine is recognized.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Ran out of other ideas so I gave a DFU revive a try. Error below, I've found minimal information on this code. Looks like it's now auto booting to dfu.

[ATTACH type="full"]60430[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Do you get SSD voltage?
I bet for SSD damage; caused by liquid spill on <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Yes, all of the voltages in the SSD 4 LANDING and SSD 2 LANDING sections of the power on sequence document are fine.

It's possible that SSD0 got zapped with PPBUS, but there's no shorts, so it feels premature to call off recovery efforts based on that. 

How would I go about getting a definitive answer on SSD issues being the cause of my stalled boot?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Looks like skipping over portions of the power on sequence that I assumed were required for later sections was a bad decision.

The first line with an issue is actually  <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL>,  <SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> and subsequent rails in that section do not come online.

The last time I saw a failure at this point in the boot sequence, it was a bad <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, however then I had 5V, not 20V on my ammeter. I pulled both <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> on the side of the board that was exposed to liquid and they were fine underneath.

Is replacing them a worthwhile idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips should be good, at least partially.

I suppose that DFU cannot write firmware partition on SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: I don't understand how the problem could be SSD related when the SSD is not even powered yet when <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> fails to go high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Also, can you elaborate on the "partially" with regards to the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, is there something I can check?

This customer is extremely interested in data recovery, so I want to explore every possible avenue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
You've said to have SSD voltages before.
"Yes, all of the voltages in the SSD 4 LANDING and SSD 2 LANDING sections of the power on sequence document are fine."

<CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip is very complex, like <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
No datasheet available, but may be some copy of another TI chip.
For example, <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> has the same pinout as <CHIP>TPS65982</CHIP>/87; not compatible, but datasheet helps to make an idea about it.
I doubt to have a problem with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, if you get 20V on input.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
According to the power on sequence document for this device:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oBr-qxYVfghYimgX6pwkNbwSjpQfYbKq/view[/URL]

<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> is supposed to go high [B]before [/B]anything in the SSD 4 LANDING and SSD 2 LANDING sections.

However, it fails to ever go high.

[B]My question is, how can the SSD be responsible for this fault (<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> not going high) when the SSD is not yet powered (And not supposed to be powered) at the time when the fault first occurs?[/B]

Thank you for your explanation on the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>! I don't get 20V after attempting a dfu revive anymore, but I did before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
So you've lost 20V input after touching <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips?
Did you reball, or replaced them?

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> may be your problem.
Check its LDOs (SYM 1 OF 4), at page 76.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
I'm not sure, unfortunately I didn't check this between the dfu operation and <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> work, but my guess is that I lost 20V after the dfu revive attempt, as my soldering doesn't often cause issues and I redid the CD3217s more than once with identical results.

I did the following:
-Replaced both CD3217s on that side of the board, observed 5v and assumed it was a result of the dfu revive attempt
-Attempted a second dfu revive, same error
-Reballed and restored both of the originals as I'd like my new chips back, still observed 5v

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> LDOs appear fine to me:
LDO0 0.8V
LDO1 3V
LDO2 1.2V
LDO3 1.8V
LDO RTC 1.5V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> is good too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Yes.
<SIGNAL>VOUT_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.36V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Can you confirm that all signals above <SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> (on diagram) are present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Haven’t actually verified clock lines with a logic analyzer, but otherwise yes

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Then the problem should be <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or T2...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Should I just replace <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or is there a more logical diagnostic step I can take first? If T2, can I replace without data loss or are the encryption keys onboard?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: Encryption keys are stored into T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message: So you would recommend just replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05 Liquid Damage Partial Power
threads.message:
Is not clear if <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, or T2.
Why would you start with T2, which is more difficult step?
